title: Formby - Beach, Woods and Coast Walk Route

images.title: Tom Pennington / Formby beach
images.caption: Formby beach. High spring tide lapping the dunes.

images.title: Graham Burnett / Formby with shale deposits
images.caption: Formby with shale deposits

images.title: stan lewis / Pinewoods in Formby.
images.caption: Pinewoods in Formby. Asy you make your way around the site look out and listen for the Natterjack toad. Formby is one of a few sites in England where they will breed. If you are here on a spring evening listen for the male's distinctive song known locally as the 'Bootle Organ'. At these times the males gather at the edge of shallow pools in the dune slacks and sing to attract a mate.

images.title: Bryan Pready / Pine trees on the dunes
images.caption: Pine trees on the dunes. This group of pine trees are the closest to the sea, are exposed to the wind.

images.title: Gary Rogers / Foredunes at Formby
images.caption: Foredunes at Formby. View northwest across the foredunes from the southern edge of the square on a scorching hot July day.

images.title: David Hawgood / Walking to the beach, Formby
images.caption: Walking to the beach. The walkers are near the edge of the dunes, which here is at the high tide mark. This photo is taken at low tide with the sea 400 metres down the beach. The track leads from the large National Trust car park to the beach.

images.title: Mark Arrowsmith / Sand Dunes, Formby
images.caption: Coastal sand dunes at Formby Point. View North West to Irish Sea.

images.title: Liz North / Red squirrel feeding, Formby nature reserve
images.caption: Red squirrel feeding, Formby nature reserve

description: Explore the beaches, sand dunes and woodland in this beautiful nature reserve in Formby. The area is famous for its wildlife with the Natterjack Toad and the Red Squirrel the major highlights. The area is run by the National Trust so you will find a series of well laid out footpaths and waymarked trails. There is a squirrel trail through the lovely pine woodlands where you can look out for the growing population of red squirrels. There's also an asparagus trail where you can learn about Formby's asparagus heritage. This trail passes through farmland with Hebridean and Herdwick sheep. If you'd like to continue your walking in the area then you could pick up the Sefton Coastal Footpath which runs past the site.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Pinewoods pub is located just to the east of the woods. They do good food and have a decent selection of ales. You can find them at Wicks Green with a postcode of L37 1PR for your sat navs.

details.subtitle: Dog Walking
details.content: The woodland and beach are ideal for dog walking so you're bound to bump into other owners on your visit. There are water bowls near the toilets and in the parking areas at Victoria Road. The Pinewoods pub mentioned above is also dog friendly.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Follow the Sefton Coastal footpath north and it will take you to the Ainsdale National Nature Reserve where there's more woodland and dunes to explore. You'll also pass the Royal Birkdale Golf Club before coming to the popular town of Southport. If you head south you can visit Crosby and see the fascinating Another Place Sculptures on Crosby Beach. The Anthony Gormley piece was created in 1997, and consists of 100 cast iron figures facing towards the sea. To the east you can pick up the Leeds and Liverpool Canal and enjoy a walk around Maghull to the Lunt Meadows Nature Reserve. For more walking ideas in the area see the Merseyside Walks page.
